(Justin, XLI,4)[PARAGRAPH:2]The new kingdom, highly urbanized and considered as one of the richest of the Orient (opulentissimum illud mille urbium Bactrianum imperium "The extremely prosperous Bactrian empire of the thousand cities" Justin, XLI,1), was to further grow in power and engage into territorial expansion to the east and the west:[PARAGRAPH:1]"The Greeks who caused Bactria to revolt grew so powerful on account of the fertility of the country that they became masters, not only of Ariana, but also of India, as Apollodorus of Artemita says: and more tribes were subdued by them than by Alexander... Their cities were Bactra (also called Zariaspa, through which flows a river bearing the same name and emptying into the Oxus), and Darapsa, and several others. Among these was Eucratidia, which was named after its ruler." (Strabo, XI.XI.I)[PARAGRAPH:2]When the ruler of neighbouring Parthia, the former satrap and self-proclaimed king Andragoras, was defeated and killed by Arsaces, the rise of the Parthian Empire cut off the Greco-Bactrians from direct contact with the Greek world. Overland trade continued at a reduced rate, while sea trade between Greek Egypt and Bactria developed.[PARAGRAPH:2]Diodotus was succeeded by his son Diodotus II, who allied himself with the Parthian Arsaces in his fight against Seleucus II:[PARAGRAPH:1]"Soon after, relieved by the death of Diodotus, Arsaces made peace and concluded an alliance with his son, also by the name of Diodotus; some time later he fought against Seleucos who came to punish the rebels, and he prevailed: the Parthians celebrated this day as the one that marked the beginning of their freedom" (Justin, XLI,4)

[TAB]During the 6th and the 8th century, the empire that ruled the Deccan region of India was the Chalukya dynasty. After fading away for some time, they came back to power during the 10th century and ruled till 12th century. The Chalukyas are essentially divided into three broad categories: The Eastern Chalukyas, ruled from the Vengi region, the Western Chalukyas who ruled from the Badami region and the Later Western Chalukyas, which ruled from Kalyani region.[NEWLINE][TAB]The most famous rulers in the empire of the Chalukyas were Pulakesin I and Pulakesin II. The ruler Pulakesin II is said to have defeated emperor Harshavardhana in a battle on the banks of the River Narmada. He also waged a battle against Mahendravarman, the Pallava ruler and conquered him and his kingdom.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Chalukya dynasty is famous for developing and encouraging art and architecture during its era. The rulers of the Chalukya dynasty were great enthusiasts of art. This is evident from the fact that they built many temples near the region of Badami. A famous example of their architecture is the Virupaksha Temple in Karnataka. The sculptures that adorn the temples are beautifully carved and sculpted and represent scenes from the famous epic Ramayana. Some of the paintings at Ajanta and Ellora cave temples are considered to belong to this period.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pulakesin II was an admirer of art and always encouraged any art form to flourish in his kingdom. He was also fond of literature and encouraged poetry to flourish in his kingdom. The three famous poets of Kannada literature Adikavi Pampa, Sri Ponna and Ranna were from this era. Pulakesin was an able administrator and his subjects were devoted to him. Though he was Hindu by religion Pulakesin was tolerant towards Buddhism as well as Jainism. He built many monasteries in his kingdom that provided shelter to almost 5000 monks. The Chalukya kingdom was truly flourishing till it declined after the 12th century.

[TAB]The term Tocharian or Tokharian has a complex history. It is based on the ethnonym Tokharoi used by Greek historians. The first Greek mention of the Tocharians appeared in the 1st century BC, when Strabo presented them as a Scythian tribe, and explained that the Tocharians together with the Assianis, Passianis and Sakaraulis took part in the destruction of the Greco-Bactrian kingdom in the second half of the 2nd century BC. These Tocharians have frequently been identified with the Yuezhi and the later (and probably related) Kushan peoples. Many scholars believe the Yuezhi originally spoke a Tocharian language. However, the debate about the origins and original language(s) of the Yuezhi and the Kushan continues, and there is no general consensus. Regardless, it is generally accepted that the Tocharians were inhabitants of the Tarim Basin who spoke Tocharian, an Indo-European language, making them the easternmost speakers of Indo-European languages in antiquity.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Tarim mummies suggest that precursors of these easternmost speakers of an Indo-European language may have lived in the region of the Tarim Basin from around 1800 BC until finally being assimilated by Uyghur Turks in the 9th century AD. This is evidenced by both the mummies and Chinese writings.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Tocharians, living along the Silk Road, had contacts with the Chinese, Persians, Indian and Turkic tribes.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Tocharians who remained in the Tarim Basin adopted Buddhism, which, like their alphabet, came from northern India in the first century of the 1st millennium, through the proselytism of Kushan monks. The Kushans and the Tocharians seem to have played a part in the Silk Road transmission of Buddhism to China. Many apparently also practised some variant of Manichaeanism.[PARAGRAPH:2]Protected by the Taklamakan Desert from steppe nomads, the Tocharian culture survived past the 7th century. It was then, during the rise of the Islamic and Turkic Empires, that the Tocharians finally vanished from history and were assimilated into various other Central Asian peoples.
TEXT.German: Der Begriff tocharisch hat eine eher komplizierte Geschichte. Er kommt von Tocharoi, den griechische Historiker benutzten. Die Griechen erwähnten die Tocharer zum ersten Mal im 1. Jahrhundert v.Chr., als Strabo sie als skytischen Stamm beschrieb, die zusammen mit anderen, kleinen Stämmen das griechisch-baktrische Königreich im 2. Jahrhundert v.Chr. eroberte. Das Volk, dass sich selbst Arshi oder Arshoi nannte, wird immer mit den Yuezhi und den später auftretenden Kuschana in Verbindung gebracht. Inwzischen ist man sich einig, dass die Yuezhi tatsächlich tocharisch, ein eigentständiges Glied der indogermanischen Sprachfamilie, gesprochen haben, bei den Kuschanen hingegen weiß man es nicht mit Sicherheit. Man weiß auch, dass die Tocharer im Tarimbecken, im heutigen Uiguristan im Westen Chinas angesiedelt waren. Damit war das Tocharische die indogermanische Sprache, die in der Antike am weitesten nach Osten verbreitet war.[PARAGRAPH:2]Im Tarimbecken wurden Mumien entdeckt, die darauf schließen lassen, dass die Tocharer von etwa 1800 v.Chr. bis ins 9. Jahrhundert n.Chr. dort siedelten, bis sie mehr und mehr von den eingefallenen Uighuren assimiliert wurden. Ähnliches behaupten chinesische Quellen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Da die Tocharer entlang der Seidenstraße gelebt haben, hatten im Lauf der Zeit Kontakte mit Chinesen, Persern, Indern und türkischen Stämmen. Wie ihr Alphabet, eine Silbenschrift, kam wie der Buddhismus aus Indien nach Tocharistan. Es gibt auch Theorien, dass sich nur durch die Handelsbeziehungen der Tocharer nach Indien und China, der Buddhismus in Letzterem ausgebreitet hat. Manche haben wohl auch eine Form des Manichäimus praktiziert.[PARAGRAPH:2]Geschützt durch die Taklamakan, hat es die tocharische Kultur geschafft, bis zum Aufstieg der türkischen und islamischen Reiche zu überleben, bis sie schließlich im Laufe der Zeit von zentralasiatischen Völkern assimiliert wurde.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Byzantine Empire, centered around the city of Constantinople, was the successor to the Roman Empire. At its height, the Byzantine Empire reached from Persia to Spain, controlling nearly all the territory that felt the lap of the Mediterranean's warm waters.[PARAGRAPH:1]When the Byzantine Empire began and the Roman Empire ceased is a point of much contention. Some historians place the beginning of the Byzantine Empire in 300 AD, when Constantine I moved the capital of the Roman Empire from Rome to a city called Byzantium (later know as Constantinople). Others place the birth of the Byzantine Empire at the end of the reign of Theodosius I, who at his death split the Roman Empire into the Western Empire, ruled from Rome, and the Eastern Empire, ruled from Constantinople.[PARAGRAPH:1]Regardless of historic debate, after the sacking of Rome in 476 AD, the Byzantine Empire was to become the foremost European nation in art, trade and stability - although not necessarily all at once. Taking the throne in 527 AD, Justinian I extended the grip of the Byzantine Empire from Constantinople to the furthest coasts of the Mediterranean Sea. However the Empire would not be able to enjoy the benefits of such territorial expansions for long, as Justinian's successor, Justin II, would begin a trend of placating the various enemies of the Empire - the Sassanid Persians, the Bulgars, and the Arabs, newly organized under Mohammed - with territory in exchange for peace.[PARAGRAPH:1]Territorial losses would continue to weaken the Byzantines until a new lineage of emperors, known as the Macedonian Emperors, arose to invigorate the Empire once again. Basil I founded the Macedonian line in 869. Under the Macedonians, the Byzantine Empire once again began to reach outwards, solidifying its hold on much of the territory neighboring Constantinople. Art flourished in their roughly two centuries of rule, as did the Greek Orthodox Church.[PARAGRAPH:1]The new millennium would be a painful one for Byzantium. Relations between the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church had been deteriorating for many years, and the conflict came to a head with the Great Schism (1054), which finally split the two religions. Militarily, increased assaults by the Seljuk Turks culminated in a resounding defeat for the Empire at the Battle of Manzikert, the Empire losing much of its freshly-gained holdings.[PARAGRAPH:1]But once again, the rise of a powerful new dynasty reversed the Empire's decline. This new dynasty, the Comnenius, sent the call to Western Europe for aid in fighting the Seljuk Turks. Pope Urban II, seeing a chance to reconquer the Holy Lands of Antioch and Jerusalem, as well as halt the squabbling of the European Kings, spread the word for the First Crusade.[PARAGRAPH:1]Through the Crusaders' efforts, the Byzantine Empire regained a portion of its lost territory. But the holy warriors of Western Europe became difficult to control, often threatening to assault the very Empire that had requested their aid. John II and Manuel I, the two most prestigious of the Comnenius emperors, held off the Crusaders and safeguarded the empire from a host of external foes, while ushering in a new era of Byzantine artistic and economic prowess.[PARAGRAPH:1]Manuel I Comnenius was the last great emperor of the Byzantines and the last Comneni. The Angeloi dynasty, successors to the Comneni, proved unable to halt the Empire's slow collapse. In 1204, the knights of the Fourth Crusade, summoned by a disposed Angeloi prince, sacked Constantinople and split the Byzantine Empire into three smaller kingdoms. Nicaea, one of these ex-Byzantine states, recaptured Constantinople years later, but all hopes of reviving the Byzantine Empire would be ended with the capture of the city by the Ottoman leader Mehmed II in 1461.
TEXT.French: vL'empire byzantin, centré autour de la ville de Constantinople, est le successeur de l'empire romain. A son apogée, l'empire byzantin s'étend de la Perse à l'Espagne, contrôlant presque tous les territoires qui bordent les eaux chaudes de la Méditerranée.[PARAGRAPH:1]La question de savoir quand débute l'empire byzantin et quand cesse l'empire romain fait l'objet de nombreux débats. Certains historiens situent le début de l'empire byzantin en 300 ap. J.C, quand Constantin Ier transfère la capitale de l'empire romain de Rome à une ville nommée Byzance (qui deviendra ensuite Constantinople). D'autres situent la naissance de l'empire byzantin à la fin du règne de Théodose Ier qui, à sa mort, divise l'empire romain entre empire occidental (gouverné par Rome) et empire oriental (gouverné par Constantinople). Quoi qu'il en soit, après le sac de Rome en 476 ap . J.C. l'empire byzantin va devenir progressivement une nation stable, extrêmement influente dans les domaines artistiques et commerciaux. Accédant au trône en 527 ap. J.C., Justinien Ier étend l'empire byzantin de Constantinople jusqu'aux côtes les plus reculées de la mer Méditerranée. Cependant, l'empire ne jouit pas longtemps des bénéfices d'une telle expansion territoriale : le successeur de Justinien Ier, Justin II, entreprend d'apaiser les divers ennemis de l'empire (les Perses sassanides, les Bulgares et les Arabes, nouvellement organisés sous le commandement de Mohammed) en leur offrant des territoires en échange de la paix.[PARAGRAPH:1]Affaiblissant les Byzantins, les pertes territoriales continuent jusqu'à ce qu'une nouvelle lignée d'empereurs (les empereurs macédoniens) surgisse pour revigorer l'empire. Basile Ier fonde la lignée macédonienne en 869. Sous les Macédoniens, l'empire byzantin reprend son expansion, consolidant son emprise dans une grande partie du territoire voisin de Constantinople. L'art et l'Eglise orthodoxe grecque connaissent un grand essor au cours de leurs deux siècles de règne.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le nouveau millénaire va s'avérer pénible pour Byzance. Les relations avec l'Eglise catholique romaine et l'Eglise orthodoxe orientale s'étant détériorées depuis des années, le conflit éclate à l'occasion du Grand schisme (1054), qui divise les deux religions. Sur le plan militaire, l'intensification des assauts par les Turcs seldjoukides se solde par une défaite écrasante pour l'empire lors de la bataille de Manzikert. L'empire y perd une grande partie de ses territoires fraîchement conquis.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mais une nouvelle fois, l'apparition d'une nouvelle dynastie inverse le déclin de l'empire. Cette nouvelle dynastie, la dynastie des Comnènes, fait appel à l'Europe occidentale pour les aider à combattre les Turcs seldjoukides. Le pape Urbain II, voyant là une occasion de reconquérir les terres sacrées d'Antioche et de Jérusalem, ainsi que d'interrompre les querelles entre les rois européens, proclame la première croisade.[PARAGRAPH:1]Grâce aux efforts des croisés, l'empire byzantin reprend une partie de ses territoires perdus. Mais les guerriers saints de l'Europe occidentale deviennent difficiles à contrôler : ils menacent à plusieurs reprises d'attaquer l'empire qui avait demandé leur aide. Jean II et Manuel Ier, les deux plus prestigieux empereurs Comnènes, parviennent à tenir les croisés à distance et à protéger l'empire d'une foule d'ennemis étrangers, tout en inaugurant une nouvelle ère de prouesses artistiques et économiques.[PARAGRAPH:1]Manuel Ier Comnène est le dernier grand empereur des Byzantins et le dernier Comnène. La dynastie des Anges, succédant aux Comnènes, s'avère incapable d'arrêter le lent déclin de l'empire. En 1204, les chevaliers de la quatrième croisade, appelés par un prince déchu, pillent Constantinople et divisent l'empire byzantin en trois Etats. Nicée, l'un de ces empires anciennement byzantins, reconquiert Constantinople des années plus tard, mais tout espoir de faire renaître l'empire byzantin s'envole lors de la capture de la ville par le chef ottoman Mehmet II en 1461.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Byzantinische Reich, in dessen Zentrum die Stadt Konstantinopel lag, war der Nachfolger des Römischen Reichs. Zu seiner Blütezeit erstreckte sich das Byzantinische Reich von Persien nach Spanien und kontrollierte beinahe alle Gebiete, die von den warmen Wellen des Mittelmeers bespült wurden.[PARAGRAPH:1]Wann das Byzantinische Reich begann und wann das Römische Reich aufhörte, ist stark umstritten. Manche Historiker legen den Beginn des Byzantinischen Reiches auf das Jahr 300 n. Chr., als Konstantin I. die Hauptstadt des Römischen Reiches aus Rom in eine Stadt namens Byzanz verlegte (das spätere Konstantinopel). Andere verlegen die Geburt des Byzantinischen Reiches an das Ende der Herrschaft Theodosius I., der bei seinem Tod das Römische Reich in ein von Rom aus regiertes Westreich und ein von Konstantinopel aus regiertes Ostreich aufteilte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Welches Ende die historische Debatte auch nehmen mag, nach der Plünderung Roms im Jahr 476 n. Chr. wurde das Byzantinische Reich zur führenden europäischen Nation in Sachen Kunst, Handel und Stabilität - jedoch nicht unbedingt alles gleichzeitig. Justinian bestieg den Thron im Jahr 527 n. Chr. und erweiterte den Machtbereich des Byzantinischen Reiches von Konstantinopel aus auf die entlegensten Küsten des Mittelmeers. Das Reich konnte sich jedoch nicht lange an den Vorteilen dieser Gebietserweiterungen erfreuen, da Justinians Nachfolger, Justin II., den späteren Brauch begründete, verschiedene Feinde des Reiches zu besänftigen - die Sassanidischen Perser, die Bulgaren und die unter Mohammed neu organisierten Araber - indem man jeweils Landbesitz gegen Frieden tauschte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Gebietsverluste schwächten die Byzantiner weiter, bis ein neues Kaisergeschlecht, bekannt als die Makedonischen Kaiser, sich erhob, um dem Reich neues Leben einzuhauchen. Basileos I. begründete im Jahr 869 die Makedonische Dynastie. Unter den Makedonen erweiterte sich das Byzantinische Reich erneut nach außen und festigte seinen Zugriff auf den Großteil des Konstantinopel umgebenden Gebiets. In den ungefähr zweihundert Jahren ihrer Herrschaft erlebte die Kunst eine Blütezeit, ebenso die Griechisch-Orthodoxe Kirche.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das neue Jahrtausend sollte für Byzanz schmerzhaft sein. Die Beziehungen zwischen der Römisch-Katholischen und der Östlich-Orthodoxen Kirche hatten sich seit vielen Jahren verschlechtert und der Streit erreichte seinen Höhepunkt mit dem Morgenländischen Schisma (1054), das die zwei Religionen endgültig voneinander trennte. Auf der militärischen Seite gipfelten die zunehmenden Angriffe der seldschukischen Türken in der Schlacht von Manzikert in einer vernichtenden Niederlage für das Reich, das viel von seinen frisch eroberten Besitzungen wieder verlor.[PARAGRAPH:1]Jedoch kehrte erneut der Aufstieg einer mächtigen neuen Dynastie den Abstieg des Reiches um. Diese neue Dynastie, die Komnenen, sandte den Ruf mit der Bitte um Unterstützung gegen die seldschukischen Türken nach Westeuropa. Papst Urban II., der darin die Möglichkeit sah, das Heilige Land in Antiochia und Jerusalem zurückzuerobern und gleichzeitig die inneren Querelen der europäischen Könige zu beenden, rief daraufhin zum Ersten Kreuzzug auf.[PARAGRAPH:1]Durch die Anstrengungen der Kreuzfahrer gewann das Byzantinische Reich einen Teil seiner verlorenen Gebiete zurück. Doch die heiligen Krieger Westeuropas wurden immer schwerer zu bändigen und drohten oft, eben jenes Reich, das um ihre Hilfe gebeten hatte, anzugreifen. Johannes II. und Manuel I., die zwei bedeutendsten Komnenischen Kaiser, wehrten die Kreuzfahrer ab und sicherten das Reich vor einer Fülle äußerer Feinde, während sie gleichzeitig eine neue Blütezeit der Byzantinischen Kunst und der Wirtschaft einläuteten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Manuel I. Komnenos war der letzte große Kaiser der Byzantiner und der letzte Komnene. Die Dynastie der Angeloi, der Nachfolger der Komnenen, erwies sich als nicht in der Lage, den langsamen Zerfall des Reichs aufzuhalten. 1204 plünderten die Ritter des Vierten Kreuzzugs auf Geheiß eines abgesetzten Angeloi-Prinzen Konstantinopel und teilten das Byzantinische Reich auf drei kleinere Königreiche auf. Nikaia, einer dieser ehemals byzantinischen Staaten, eroberte Jahre später Konstantinopel zurück, doch alle Hoffnung auf eine Neubelebung des Byzantinischen Reiches sollte 1453 mit der Eroberung der Stadt durch den osmanischen Herrscher Mehmet II. zu Ende gehen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'Impero Bizantino, costruito attorno alla città di Costantinopoli, succedette all'Impero Romano. Al suo culmine l'Impero Bizantino si estendeva dalla Persia alla Spagna e controllava quasi tutto il territorio che si affacciava sulle calde acque del Mediterraneo.[PARAGRAPH:1]La questione su quando sia iniziato l'Impero Bizantino e quando sia finito quello Romano è molto controversa. Alcuni storici pongono l'inizio dell'Impero Bizantino nel 300 d.C., quando Costantino spostò la capitale dell'impero da Roma a una città chiamata Bisanzio (più tardi conosciuta come Costantinopoli). Altri pongono la nascita dell'Impero Bizantino alla fine del regno di Teodosio, che alla sua morte divise l'Impero Romano in Occidentale, comandato da Roma, e Orientale, governato da Costantinopoli.[PARAGRAPH:1]A prescindere dai dibattiti storici, dopo il sacco di Roma nel 476 d.C., l'Impero Bizantino divenne la nazione più importante in Europa per l'arte, il commercio e la stabilità. Salito al trono nel 527 d.C., Giustiniano estese il dominio dell'Impero Bizantino da Costantinopoli alla costa più lontana del Mar Mediterraneo. L'impero però non godette a lungo dei benefici di una tale espansione territoriale, visto che il successore di Giustiniano, Giustino II, iniziò la tendenza a placare i diversi nemici dell'impero (i Persiani Sasanidi, i Bulgari e gli Arabi, di recente organizzatisi sotto Maometto) scambiando territori con la pace.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le perdite territoriali avrebbero continuato a indebolire i Bizantini fino a quando una nuova stirpe di imperatori, i Macedoni, sorse a rinvigorire ancora una volta l'impero. Basilio I fondò la stirpe macedone nell'869 d.C.; sotto i Macedoni l'Impero Bizantino cominciò ancora una volta a espandersi, consolidando il proprio dominio su gran parte del territorio attorno a Costantinopoli. Nei circa due secoli in cui regnarono i Macedoni fiorirono l'arte e la Chiesa greca ortodossa.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il nuovo millennio sarebbe stato doloroso per Bisanzio. Le relazioni tra la Chiesa Cattolica Romana e la Chiesa Orientale Ortodossa andavano peggiorando da molti anni, e il conflitto arrivò al culmine con il Grande Scisma (1054), che divise le due religioni. Dal punto di vista militare, si andarono moltiplicando gli assalti da parte dei Turchi selgiuchidi, che culminarono in una cocente sconfitta nella Battaglia di Manzikert, per cui l'impero perse gran parte delle terre da poco conquistate.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ma ancora una volta, l'ascesa di una nuova potente dinastia rovesciò le sorti dell'impero. La nuova dinastia, quella dei Comneni, inviò una richiesta di aiuto all'Europa occidentale per combattere i Turchi selgiuchidi. Il papa Urbano II intravide la possibilità di riconquistare le Sacre Terre di Antiochia e Gerusalemme, e di fermare gli scontri dei re europei e istituì così la Prima Crociata.[PARAGRAPH:1]Grazie agli sforzi dei crociati, l'Impero Bizantino riacquistò una parte dei territori perduti. Ma i guerrieri religiosi dell'Europa occidentale divennero difficili da controllare e spesso minacciavano di attaccare lo stesso impero che aveva richiesto il loro aiuto. Giovanni II e Manuele I, i due più importanti imperatori Comneni, tennero a bada i crociati e salvaguardarono l'impero da molti nemici, mentre introducevano una nuova era di valore artistico ed economico per Bisanzio.[PARAGRAPH:1]Manuele I Comneno fu l'ultimo grande imperatore bizantino e l'ultimo dei Comneni. La dinastia degli Angelo, successa a quella dei Comneni, si dimostrò incapace di fermare il lento collasso dell'impero. Nel 1204 i cavalieri della Quarta Crociata, richiamati da un principe Angelo deposto, saccheggiarono Costantinopoli e divisero l'Impero Bizantino in tre regni più piccoli. Quello di Nicea riconquistò Costantinopoli anni più tardi, ma tutte le speranze di far rivivere l'Impero Bizantino terminarono con la cattura della città da parte del sultano Ottomano Mehmed II, nel 1461.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El Imperio Bizantino, construido alrededor de la ciudad de Constantinopla, fue el sucesor del Imperio Romano. En su apogeo, el imperio se extendía desde Persia hasta España, y controlaba casi todos los territorios bañados por las cálidas aguas del Mediterráneo.[PARAGRAPH:1]El momento exacto en el que nace el Imperio Bizantino y desaparece el Imperio Romano es un tema muy controvertido. Algunos historiadores sitúan el nacimiento del bizantino en el año 300 d. C., cuando Constantino I trasladó la capital del Imperio Romano a una ciudad llamada Bizancio(conocida más adelante como Constantinopla). Para otros, el nacimiento del imperio se produjo al finalizar el reinado de Teodosio I, cuando se dividió el Imperio Romano en dos mitades, la occidental gobernada desde Roma, y la oriental, desde Constantinopla.[PARAGRAPH:1]Al margen de este debate histórico, tras el saqueo de Roma (476 d. C.), el Imperio Bizantino se vio catapultado al primer lugar de Europa en los ámbitos del arte, el comercio y la estabilidad... aunque no siempre al mismo tiempo. Tras subir al trono en el año 527 d. C., Justiniano I extendió la autoridad del imperio desde Constantinopla hasta los últimos confines del Mediterráneo. Sin embargo, el imperio no podría disfrutar durante mucho tiempo de los beneficios de esta expansión, puesto que el sucesor de Justiniano, Justino II, inició una política de apaciguamiento con los diferentes enemigos de Bizancio (la Persia sasánida, los búlgaros, y los árabes, unidos bajo una misma bandera por Mahoma) comprando su indulgencia con tierras.[PARAGRAPH:1]Las pérdidas territoriales continuarían debilitando a los bizantinos hasta que el advenimiento de una nueva dinastía, llamada macedónica, volviera a vigorizar el imperio. Basilio I fundó esta dinastía en el 869. Bajo los emperadores macedónicos, el Imperio Bizantino volvió a expandirse y consolidó su autoridad sobre la mayor parte de los territorios que rodeaban Constantinopla. Durante los casi dos siglos que duró esta dinastía, florecieron el arte y la Iglesia ortodoxa griega.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sin embargo, el nuevo milenio sería duro para Bizancio. Las relaciones entre la Iglesia católica romana y la Iglesia ortodoxa oriental llevaban deteriorándose muchos años, y el conflicto llegó a su punto álgido en el Gran Cisma(1054), que dividió definitivamente ambas religiones. Desde el punto de vista militar, el aumento de los ataques de los turcos selyúcidas culminó en la sonora derrota del imperio en la batalla de Manzikert, donde Bizancio perdió gran parte de las tierras que acababa de ganar.[PARAGRAPH:1]Pero, una vez más, la aparición de una nueva dinastía volvió a revertir el declive del imperio. Esta dinastía, la de los Comneno, recurrió a Europa occidental en busca de ayuda contra los turcos selyúcidas. El papa Urbano II, viendo la ocasión de reconquistar Tierra Santa (Antioquía y Jerusalén) y de poner fin a los mezquinos enfrentamientos entre los monarcas de Europa, empezó a predicar la Primera Cruzada.[PARAGRAPH:1]Gracias a los esfuerzos de los cruzados, s, el Imperio Bizantino pudo recuperar parte de sus territorios. Pero los guerreros de Europa occidental eran muy difíciles de controlar, y en muchas ocasiones amenazaron con atacar el mismo imperio que había solicitado su ayuda. Juan II y Manuel I, los dos Comneno más prestigiosos, mantuvieron a raya a los cruzados y defendieron al imperio de un sinfín de enemigos extranjeros, al tiempo que impulsaban una nueva era de gloria artística y desarrollo económico.[PARAGRAPH:1]Manuel I Comneno fue el último gran emperador de Bizancio, así como el último de los miembros de su dinastía. La dinastía de los Angelo, sucesores de los Comneno, fue incapaz de frenar el lento declive del imperio. En 1204, los caballeros de la Cuarta Cruzada, llamados por un depuesto príncipe Angelo, saquearon Constantinopla y dividieron el imperio en reinos menores. Nicea, uno de estos estados, recuperó Constantinopla años después, pero todas las esperanzas de reverdecer los laureles del imperio se desmoronaron tras la caída de la ciudad en manos del sultán otomano Mehmet II en 1461.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Gokturks, who originated from the Ashina tribe who were natives of today's Xiang Uygur, were the first Turkic tribe to use the name "Turk" as a political name. The Gokturks established the first known Turkic state around 552 under the leadership of Bumin/Tuman Khan/Khaghan (died 552) and his sons, and expanded rapidly to rule wide territories in Central Asia.[PARAGRAPH:2]With the collapse of Hunnish power in Asia, leadership of the Turks was taken over by the Gokturks, who inherited their traditions and administrative experience. From 552 to 745, Gokturkish leadership bound together the nomadic Turkish tribes into an empire, which finally fell to internal conflicts and to defeats by China. The kingdom received missionaries from the Buddhists, Manicheans, and Nestorian Christians, but remained primarily shamanistic. The great difference between the Gokturkish empire and its Hunnish predecessor was that the Gokturks' temporary Khans (lords) were subordinate to a sovereign authority that was left in the hands of a dynasty of tribal chiefs.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 552, Tuman defeated the last Rouran Khan, A-na-kuei . Tuman's brother Istami (died 576) collaborated with the Persian Sassanids to defeat and destroy the White Huns, which drove the Avars into Europe. Both rival state in north China paid large tributes to the Gokturks from 581. This first Gokturkish empire split in two after the death of the last of Tuman's sons (circa 584). These were successfully played off against each other by Sui and Tang Dynasty China. The Eastern Khanate became formally subordinate to the Chinese Emperor; the Western Khan of that time was Istami's son Tardu, who almost succeeded in reuniting the Gokturkish empire around 600. However, Chinese diplomacy incited a revolt of his vassals, and Tardu's life and reign were cut short in 603. New attacks on China by the Turks of the Eastern Khanate failed, and its Khan Hsien was brought down by a revolt of his vassals (626-630), instigated by Emperor Tanng Taizong, who took him prisoner. The Western Khan Tung Sche-hu was murdered in 630 despite strong support by the Byzantine Empire against the Persians. By 659 the Tang Emperor of China could claim to rule the entire Silk Road as far as Po-sse (Persia). The Turks now carried Chinese titles and fought by their side in their wars.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nonetheless, Ilteris Sad and his brother Bakcor Qapagan Khan managed to found a new realm of "wild" Turks, which in a series of wars from 681 onward gained control of the steppes beyond the Great Wall of China, extending by 705 to threaten Arab control of Transoxiana. Their power centered at the Changai Mountains. The son of Ilteris, Bilge, was also a strong leader, but at his death in 734, the empire declined. They ultimately fell to a series of internal crises and renewed Chinese campaigns. After Kutluk (Ko-lo) Khan 's military victory in 744, the successors to the Gokturks became their more China-friendly junior partners, known as the Uighurs.

In the seventh century, in the region between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea, a free Jewish state was established. Its people were a mix of Khazar Turks, whom were part of the Gok Turkic Migration, the Huns, the Bulgars, and the Caucasians. The story of the Khazar Empire begins when the infant-empire Khagan Bulan heard from an Arab mullah, a Christian priest, and a Jewish rabbi on the reasons why Khazaria should adopt each of their religions. After much thought, Bulan decided to adopt the Jewish faith. Nowhere else in the world, has a non-Jewish nation undergone such a conversion as Bulan faced the Muslim expansion of the South, and the Christian expansion to the west. A few wars between the Khazars and Arabs prevented Islam from spreading across all of eastern Europe at a time when Islam was attracting many followers. It also became a place of safety and refuge for the Jewish people, as the rest of the world were persecuted.[PARAGRAPH:2]Khazar power begins at about 650 BC, when the Turkic kingdom formed after the breakup of the Gok Turks and the collapse of their rival the Avars. Khazar culture was molded around the Gok Turks, with the Khagan holding supreme power and the Khagan Bek being the military power. The Khazars used a runic script that originated in Mongolia as their language. Most of the Turkish groups of the period used the same type of language.[PARAGRAPH:2]Arab scholars of the time provide the most knowledge of the Khazars. An 11th century Muslim chronicler elaborated on the man who brought the Jewish faith to Khazaria. His writings explain how a single Khazar Jew, who had a high military rank, converted all the other Khazars to Judaism. The chronicler went on to explain how the Khazars observed Judaism. Obadiah, one of Bulan's descendants, consolidated the newly-adopted religion with the construction of synogogues and invited Jewish scholars to confince other doubters among the aristocracy. However, it was not only the military elite and the nobles who were converted. The common people embraced the new religion with open arms. Pagan shamanism was the Khazar's original religion, remained in place as were other religions. Incredibely, a seven-strong Supreme Court with representatives of all faiths was established to ensure fair hearing for all people. Such religious tolerance was unheard of.[PARAGRAPH:2]Although the Khazars were nomadiv people, the conversion to Judaism rapidly opted for a more settled existance with Khazaria prospering from farming, the production of goods, and trading. Khazaria also did play a role in the defeat of Persia in the 7th century, allying it self with the Turks and the Byzantines. There wer also a series of wars in the 8th centurey against the Arabs that established Khazaria's souther borders at the Caucasus Mountains. However, the Khazars are associated with a period of peace along the steppe because they were more concerned with commerce than warfare.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Khazars were very coopertive with their neighbors such that the Byzantines build a wall for them at the city of Sarkel along the Don River. Byzantine emporors Justinian II and Constantine V both took a Khazar wife. Khazar also brought many new technologies in since Jews from all over the world came in search of a Jewish beacon. All this helped to strengthen Khazaria and make it into a cosmopolitan and a progressive civilization.[PARAGRAPH:2]At the empires greatest extent at 850, it stretched from the Black to the Caspian sea. The waterways were trading links and the Khazars built the city of Kiev, later becoming its capital. The most enduring of Khazar capitals was Itil. It had a trading post, an administrative center, and religious hearland for the Jews. It also had an Islamic mosque to serve the Muslim population. Khazar power ended under Svyatoslav, the ruler of Kiev. Khazaria was then taken over by the neighboring Pechenegs, Oghuz, and Byzantine peoples. Khazar traders faced difficult circumstances during these times and all mention of them ends. The Penchenegs who had much of Khazar land did not focus on trade, and distrupted the trade with Eastern Europe.
TEXT.French: Au septième siècle, dans la région entre la Mer Noire et la mer caspienne, un état juif libre a été établi. Ses personnes étaient un mélange des Turcs de Khazar, qui faisaient partie de la migration de Gok Turkic, les huns, le Bulgars, et les Caucasiens. L'histoire de l'empire de Khazar commence quand l'enfant en bas âge-empire Khagan Bulan reçu des nouvelles un mollah arabe, un prêtre chrétien, et un rabbin juif sur les raisons pour lesquelles Khazaria devrait adopter chacune de leurs religions. Après beaucoup de pensée, Bulan a décidé d'adopter la foi juive. Nulle part autrement dans le monde, a une nation non-Juive subie une telle conversion que Bulan a fait face à l'expansion musulmane des sud, et l'expansion chrétienne à l'ouest. Quelques guerres entre le Khazars et les Arabes ont empêché l'Islam d'écarter à travers toute l'Europe de l'Est à un moment où l'Islam attirait beaucoup de disciples. C'est également devenu un endroit de la sûreté et refuge pour les personnes juives, pendant que le reste du monde étaient persécutés.[PARAGRAPH:2]La puissance de Khazar commence à environ 650 AVANT JÉSUS CHRIST, quand le royaume de Turkic a formé après la dissolution des Turcs de Gok et l'effondrement de leur rival l'Avars. La culture de Khazar a été moulée autour des Turcs de Gok, avec le Khagan tenant la puissance suprême et le Khagan Bek étant la puissance militaire. Le Khazars a employé un manuscrit runic qui a provenu de la Mongolie en tant que leur langue. La plupart des groupes turcs de la période ont employé le même type de langue.[PARAGRAPH:2]Les disciples arabes du temps fournissent la plupart de connaissance du Khazars. Un chroniqueur musulman du 11ème siècle a élaboré sur l'homme qui a apporté la foi juive à Khazaria. Ses écritures expliquent comment un juif simple de Khazar, qui a eu un rang élevé de militaires, a converti tout autre Khazars en judaïsme. Le chroniqueur a continué pour expliquer comment le Khazars a observé le judaïsme. Obadiah, un des descendants de Bulan, a consolidé la religion nouveau-adoptée avec la construction des synogogues et a invité les disciples juifs au confince d'autres douteurs parmi l'aristocratie. Cependant, c'était non seulement l'élite militaire et les nobles qui ont été convertis. Les gens du commun ont embrassé la nouvelle religion avec les bras ouverts. Le shamanism païen était la religion originale du Khazar, restée en place de même que d'autres religions. Incredibely, une cour suprême sept-forte avec des représentants de toutes les fois a été établi pour assurer l'audition juste pour toutes les personnes. Une telle tolérance religieuse était inconnue.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bien que le Khazars aient été des personnes de nomadiv, la conversion en judaïsme a rapidement opté pour un existance plus arrangé avec Khazaria prospérant de l'affermage, de la production des marchandises, et du commerce. Khazaria également a joué un rôle dans la défaite de Perse au 7ème siècle, l'alliant individu avec les Turcs et le Byzantines. Là wer également qu'une série de guerres dans le 8ème centurey contre les Arabes qui ont établi le souther de Khazaria encadre aux montagnes de Caucase. Cependant, le Khazars sont associés à une période de paix le long de la steppe parce qu'elles davantage ont été concernées par le commerce que la guerre.[PARAGRAPH:2]Le Khazars étaient très coopertive avec leurs voisins tels que la construction de Byzantines un mur pour eux à la ville de Sarkel le long du fleuve de Don. Les emporors bizantins Justinian II et Constantine V tous les deux ont pris une épouse de Khazar. Khazar également a apporté beaucoup de nouvelles technologies dedans puisque les juifs de sont partout dans le monde venus à la recherche d'une balise juive. Tout ceci a aidé à renforcer Khazaria et à le transformer en une civilisation cosmopolite et progressive.[PARAGRAPH:2]À la plus grande ampleur d'empires à 850, il s'est étendu du noir à la mer caspienne. Les voies d'eau commerçaient des liens et le Khazars a construit la ville de Kiev, devenant plus tard son capital. La résistance des capitaux de Khazar était Itil. Elle a eu un comptoir commercial, un centre administratif, et le hearland religieux pour les juifs. Elle a également eu une mosquée islamique pour servir la population musulmane. La puissance de Khazar a fini sous Svyatoslav, la règle de Kiev. Khazaria a été alors succédé par le Pechenegs voisin, l'Oghuz, et les peuples bizantins. Les commerçants de Khazar ont fait face à des circonstances difficiles pendant ces périodes et toute la mention de elles des extrémités. Le Penchenegs qui a eu beaucoup de terre de Khazar ne s'est pas concentré sur le commerce, et distrupted le commerce avec l'Europe de l'Est.
TEXT.German: Im 7. Jahrhundert in der Region zwischen dem Schwarzen Meer und dem kaspischen Meer, wurde ein freier jüdischer Zustand hergestellt. Seine Leute waren eine Mischung der Khazar Türken, die ein Teil der Gok Turkic Migration, die Hunnen, das Bulgars und die Kaukasier waren. Die Geschichte des Khazar Reiches fängt wenn das Kindreich Khagan Bulan an, das von einem arabischen Mulla, von einem christlichen Priester und von einem jüdischen Rabbiner auf den Gründen gehört wird, warum Khazaria jede ihrer Religionen annehmen sollte. Nach vielem Gedanken entschied Bulan, den jüdischen Glauben anzunehmen. Nirgendwo sonst in der Welt, hat eine nicht-Jüdische Nation, die solch einer Umwandlung durchgemacht wird, der Bulan die moslemische Expansion des Südens gegenüberstellte, und der christlichen Expansion zum Westen. Einige Kriege zwischen dem Khazars und den Arabern verhinderten Islam am Verbreiten über den ganzen Osteuropa, zu einer Zeit als Islam viele Nachfolger anzog. Es wurde auch ein Ort der Sicherheit und Schutz für die jüdischen Leute, während der Rest der Welt verfolgt wurden.[PARAGRAPH:2]Khazar Energie fängt an ungefähr 650 BC an, als das Turkic Königreich nach dem Auseinanderbrechen der Gok Türken und dem Einsturz ihres Rivalen das Avars sich bildete. Khazar Kultur wurde um die Gok Türken geformt, wenn das Khagan Oberste Energie hält und dem Khagan Bek, das die militärische Energie ist. Das Khazars benutzte einen runic Index, der in Mongolei als ihre Sprache entstand. Die meisten türkischen Gruppen der Periode benutzten die gleiche Art der Sprache.[PARAGRAPH:2]Arabische Gelehrte der Zeit stellen das meiste Wissen des Khazars zur Verfügung. Ein moslemischer Chronist des 11. Jahrhunderts arbeitete auf dem Mann aus, der Khazaria den jüdischen Glauben holte. Seine Schreiben erklären, wie ein einzelner Khazar Jude, der einen hohen Militärrank hatte, alles andere Khazars in Judentum umwandelte. Der Chronist fuhr fort, zu erklären, wie das Khazars Judentum beobachtete. Obadiah, einer von Nachkommen Bulans, vereinigte die neu-angenommene Religion mit dem Aufbau von synogogues und lud jüdische Gelehrte zum confince andere Zweifler unter der Aristokratie ein. Jedoch war es nicht nur die militärische Auslese und die Adligen, die umgewandelt wurden. Die gewöhnlichen Leute umfaßten die neue Religion mit den geöffneten Armen. Heidnisches shamanism war die des Khazars ursprüngliche Religion, an der richtigen Stelle geblieben, wie andere Religionen. Incredibely, ein sieben-starkes Höchstes Gericht mit Repräsentanten aller Glauben wurde hergestellt, um angemessene Hörfähigkeit für alle Leute sicherzustellen. Solche fromme Toleranz war von ungehört.[PARAGRAPH:2]Obgleich das Khazars nomadiv Leute waren, entschied die Umwandlung zum Judentum schnell für ein vereinbartes existance mit Khazaria, das vom Bewirtschaften, von der Produktion von Waren und vom Handeln sich erweitert. Khazaria auch spielte eine Rolle in der Niederlage von Persien im 7. Jahrhundert und verband sie Selbst mit den Türken und dem Byzantines. Dort wer, auch, das eine Reihe Kriege im 8. centurey gegen die Araber, die souther Khazarias herstellten, an den Kaukasus Bergen einfaßt. Jedoch sind das Khazars mit einer Periode des Friedens entlang der Steppe verbunden, weil sie mehr mit Handel als Kriegsführung betroffen wurden.[PARAGRAPH:2]Das Khazars waren mit ihren Nachbarn so daß der Byzantines Bau eine Wand für sie an der Stadt von Sarkel entlang dem anziehenfluß sehr coopertive. Byzantinische emporors Justinian II und Constantine V beide nahmen eine Khazar Frau. Khazar holte auch viele neue Technologien innen, da Juden von auf der ganzen Erde auf der Suche nach einem jüdischen Leuchtfeuer kamen. Alles half dieses, Khazaria zu verstärken und es in eine Welt- und progressive Zivilisation zu bilden.[PARAGRAPH:2]Am größten Umfang der Reiche bei 850, dehnte er vom Schwarzen zum kaspischen Meer aus. Die Wassern-Strasse handelten Verbindungen und das Khazars errichtete die Stadt von Kiew und später wurde sein Kapital. Das Aushalten der Khazar Kapitalien war Itil. Es hatte einen handelnden Pfosten, eine Verwaltungsstelle und frommes hearland für die Juden. Es hatte auch eine islamische Moschee, zum der moslemischen Bevölkerung zu dienen. Khazar Energie beendete unter Svyatoslav, die Lehre von Kiew. Khazaria wurde dann vom benachbarten Pechenegs, vom Oghuz und von den byzantinischen Völkern übernommen. Khazar Händler stellten schwierige Umstände während dieser Zeiten und aller Erwähnung von ihnen Enden gegenüber. Das Penchenegs, das viel von Khazar Land hatte, konzentrierte nicht auf Handel und distrupted den Handel mit Osteuropa.
TEXT.Italian: Nel settimo secolo, nella regione fra il Mar Nero ed il mare caspico, un ebreo libero dichiara è stato stabilito. La relativa gente era una miscela dei Turchi di Khazar, quale facevano parte dell'espansione di Gok Turkic, i Huns, il Bulgars ed i Caucasians. La storia dell'impero di Khazar comincia quando l'infante-impero Khagan Bulan ascoltato di un mullah arabo, di un priest cristiano e di un rabbi ebreo sulle ragioni per le quali Khazaria dovrebbe adottare ciascuna delle loro religioni. Dopo molto pensiero, Bulan ha deciso adottare la fede ebrea. In nessun posto altrimenti nel mondo, ha una nazione non-Ebrea subita una tal conversione come Bulan ha affrontato l'espansione musulmana del sud e l'espansione cristiana all'ovest. Alcune guerre fra il Khazars e gli arabi hanno impedito l'Islam la diffusione attraverso tutta l'Europa Orientale in un momento in cui l'Islam stava attraendo molti seguicamme. Inoltre si è trasformato in in un posto di sicurezza ed in rifugio per la gente ebrea, mentre il resto del mondo persecuted.[PARAGRAPH:2]L'alimentazione di Khazar comincia BC a circa 650, quando il regno di Turkic ha formato dopo il disfacimento dei Turchi di Gok ed il crollo del loro rivale il Avars. La coltura di Khazar è stata modellata intorno ai Turchi di Gok, con l'alimentazione suprema della tenuta di Khagan e il Khagan Bek che è l'alimentazione militare. Il Khazars ha usato uno scritto runic che ha provenuto in Mongolia come loro lingua. La maggior parte dei gruppi turchi del periodo hanno usato lo stesso tipo di lingua.[PARAGRAPH:2]Gli eruditi arabi del tempo forniscono la maggior parte della conoscenza del Khazars. Un chronicler musulmano di undicesimo secolo ha elaborato sull'uomo che ha portato la fede ebrea a Khazaria. Le sue scritture spiegano come un singolo ebreo di Khazar, che ha avuto un alto Rank dei militari, ha convertito tutto il altro Khazars in Judaism. Il chronicler ha continuato a spiegare come il Khazars ha osservato il Judaism. Obadiah, uno dei discendenti del Bulan, ha consolidato la religione nuovo-adottata con la costruzione degli synogogues ed ha invitato gli eruditi ebrei al confince altri doubters fra il aristocracy. Tuttavia, era non solo l'elite militare ed i nobili che sono stati convertiti. La gente comune ha abbracciato la nuova religione con le armi aperte. Lo shamanism Pagan era la religione originale del Khazar, rimasta sul posto come erano altre religioni. Incredibely, una Corte suprema sette-forte con i rappresentanti di tutta la fede è stato stabilito per accertare l'udienza giusta per tutta la gente. Tale tolleranza religiosa era unheard di.[PARAGRAPH:2]Anche se il Khazars era la gente del nomadiv, la conversione a Judaism ha optato velocemente per un existance depositato con Khazaria che prospera dall'agricoltura, dalla produzione delle merci e dal commercio. Khazaria inoltre ha svolto un ruolo nella sconfitta della Persia nel settimo secolo, alleante lo auto con i Turchi e il Byzantines. Là wer inoltre che una serie di guerre nell'ottavo centurey contro gli arabi che hanno stabilito il souther del Khazaria borders alle montagne del Caucaso. Tuttavia, il Khazars è associato con un periodo di pace lungo la steppa perché di più sono state interessate del commercio che la guerra.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il Khazars era molto coopertive con i loro vicini tali che la configurazione di Byzantines una parete per loro alla città di Sarkel lungo il fiume di indoss. I emporors Byzantine Justinian II e Constantine V entrambi hanno preso una moglie di Khazar. Khazar inoltre ha portato molte nuove tecnologie dentro poiché gli ebrei da dappertutto sono venuto alla ricerca di un falò ebreo. Tutto questo ha contribuito a rinforzare Khazaria e trasformarlo una civilizzazione cosmopolita e progressiva.[PARAGRAPH:2]Al limite più grande degli imperi a 850, ha allungato dal nero al mare caspico. I canali navigabili stavano commerciando i collegamenti e il Khazars ha costruito la città di Kiev, successivamente trasformantesi nel relativo capitale. Resistere dei capitali di Khazar era Itil. Ha avuto un alberino di commercio, un centro amministrativo e hearland religioso per gli ebrei. Inoltre ha avuto un mosque islamico per servire la popolazione musulmana. L'alimentazione di Khazar si è conclusa sotto Svyatoslav, il righello di Kiev. Khazaria allora è stato rilevato dal Pechenegs vicino, dal Oghuz e dalla gente Byzantine. I commercianti di Khazar hanno affrontato le circostanze difficili durante questi periodi e tutta la menzione di loro estremità. Il Penchenegs che ha avuto molta della terra di Khazar non ha messo a fuoco su commercio e distrupted il commercio con l'Europa Orientale.
TEXT.Spanish: En el séptimo siglo, en la región entre el Mar Negro y el mar caspio, un estado judío libre fue establecido. Su gente era una mezcla de los turcos de Khazar, que eran parte de la migración de Gok Turkic, los Huns, el Bulgars, y los caucásicos. La historia del imperio de Khazar comienza cuando el infante-imperio Khagan Bulan recibido noticias un mullah árabe, un sacerdote cristiano, y un rabino judío en las razones por las que Khazaria debe adoptar cada uno de sus religiones. Después de mucho pensamiento, Bulan decidía a adoptar la fe judía. En ninguna parte en el mundo, tiene una nación no-Judía experimentada una conversión tal que Bulan hizo frente a la extensión musulmana del sur, y la extensión cristiana al oeste. Algunas guerras entre el Khazars y los árabes evitaron que el Islam se separara a través de toda la Europa Oriental en un momento en que el Islam atraía muchos seguidores. También se convirtió en un lugar de la seguridad y refugio para la gente judía, mientras que el resto del mundo fue perseguido.[PARAGRAPH:2]La energía de Khazar comienza aproximadamente 650 A.C., cuando el reino de Turkic formó después de la desintegración de los turcos de Gok y del derrumbamiento de su rival el Avars. La cultura de Khazar fue moldeada alrededor de los turcos de Gok, con el Khagan llevando a cabo energía suprema y el Khagan Bek que era la energía militar. El Khazars utilizó una escritura runic que originó en Mongolia como su lengua. La mayor parte de los grupos turcos del período utilizaron el mismo tipo de lengua.[PARAGRAPH:2]Los eruditos árabes del tiempo proporcionan la mayoría del conocimiento del Khazars. Un cronista musulmán del 11mo siglo elaboró en el hombre que trajo la fe judía a Khazaria. Sus escrituras explican cómo un solo judío de Khazar, que tenía una alta fila de los militares, convirtió todo el otro Khazars al judaísmo. El cronista se encendió explicar cómo el Khazars observó judaísmo. Obadiah, uno de los descendientes de Bulan, consolidó la religión nuevo-adoptada con la construcción de synogogues e invitó a eruditos judíos al confince otros doubters entre la aristocracia. Sin embargo, era no sólo la élite militar y los nobles que fueron convertidos. El pueblo abrazó la nueva religión con los brazos abiertos. El shamanism Pagan era la religión original del Khazar, permanecida en lugar al igual que otras religiones. Incredibely, un Tribunal Supremo siete-fuerte con los representantes de todas las fes fue establecido para asegurar la audiencia justa para toda la gente. Tal tolerancia religiosa era unheard de.[PARAGRAPH:2]Aunque el Khazars era gente del nomadiv, la conversión al judaísmo optó rápidamente por un existance colocado con Khazaria que prosperaba de cultivar, de la producción de mercancías, y de negociar. Khazaria también desempeñó un papel en la derrota de Persia en el 7mo siglo, aliándolo uno mismo con los turcos y el Byzantines. Allí wer también que una serie de guerras en el 8vo centurey contra los árabes que establecieron el souther de Khazaria confina en las montañas del Cáucaso. Sin embargo, el Khazars se asocia a un período de la paz a lo largo de la estepa porque fueron referidas más a comercio que la guerra.[PARAGRAPH:2]El Khazars era muy coopertive con sus vecinos tales que la estructura de Byzantines una pared para ellos en la ciudad de Sarkel a lo largo del río del poner. Los emporors Byzantine Justinian II y Constantina V ambos tomaron a esposa de Khazar. Khazar también trajo muchas nuevas tecnologías adentro puesto que los judíos de por todo el mundo vinieron en busca de un faro judío. Todo el esto ayudó a consolidar Khazaria y a hacerlo en una civilización cosmopolita y progresiva.[PARAGRAPH:2]En el grado más grande de los imperios en 850, estiró del negro al mar caspio. Los canales negociaban acoplamientos y el Khazars construyó la ciudad de Kiev, convirtiéndose en más adelante su capital. El aguantar de los capitales de Khazar era Itil. Tenía un poste que negociaba, un centro administrativo, y hearland religioso para los judíos. También tenía una mezquita islámica para servir a la población musulmana. La energía de Khazar terminó debajo de Svyatoslav, la regla de Kiev. Khazaria entonces fue asumido el control por el Pechenegs vecino, el Oghuz, y la gente Byzantine. Los comerciantes de Khazar hicieron frente a circunstancias difíciles durante estas épocas y toda la mención de ellas los extremos. El Penchenegs que tenía mucha de tierra de Khazar no se centró en comercio, y distrupted el comercio con Europa Oriental.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Qin were a dynasty that ruled China from 221 BC to 216 BC. The Qin are known as the first imperial dynasty.[PARAGRAPH:2]Feizi, a descendant of the ancient political advisor Gao Yao, was granted rule over Qin City. During the rule of King Xiao of Zhou, the eighth king of the Zhou Dynasty, this area became known as the state of Qin. In 897 BC, under the regency of Gonghe, the area became a dependency allotted for the purpose of raising and breeding horses. One of Feizi's descendants, Duke Zhuang, became favoured by King Ping of Zhou, the thirteenth king in that line. As a reward, Zhuang's son, Duke Xiang, was sent eastward as the leader of a war expedition, during which he formally established the Qin.[NEWLINE][TAB]Qin state first sent a military expedition into central China in 672 BC, though it did not engage in any serious incursions due to the threat from neighbouring tribesmen. By the dawn of the fourth century BC, however, the neighbouring tribes had all been either subdued or conquered, and the stage was set for the rise of Qin expansionism.[PARAGRAPH:2]Lord Shang Yang, a Qin statesman, introduced a number of militarily advantageous reforms from 361 BC until his death in 338 BC, and also helped construct the Qin capital, Xianyang. This latter accomplishment commenced in the mid-fourth century BC; the resulting city greatly resembled the capitals of other Warring States.[PARAGRAPH:2]Of Shang Yang's reforms, the most notable one was advocating the philosophy of Legalism, which encouraged practical and ruthless warfare. In contrast, during the Zhou Dynasty and the ensuing Warring States Period, the prevalent philosophy had dictated war as a gentleman's activity; military commanders were instructed to respect what they perceived to be Heaven's laws in battle. For example, during the Warring States Period, Duke Xiang of Song was at war with the state of Chu, and had an opportunity to attack the enemy force, commanded by Zhu, while they were crossing a river. Instead, however, he waited for them to finish crossing, and allowed them to marshal their forces. He was decisively defeated in the ensuing battle, and when, later, his advisors admonished him for such excessive courtesy to the enemy, he retorted, "The sage does not crush the feeble, nor give the order for attack until the enemy have formed their ranks." The Qin disregarded this military tradition, taking advantage of their enemy's weaknesses. A nobleman in the state of Wei accused the Qin state of being "avaricious, perverse, eager for profit, and without sincerity. It knows nothing about etiquette, proper relationships, and virtuous conduct, and if there be an opportunity for material gain, it will disregard its relatives as if they were animals." It was this Legalist thought combined with strong leadership from long-lived rulers, openness to employ talented men from other states, and little internal opposition that gave the Qin such a strong political base.[PARAGRAPH:2]Another advantage of the Qin was that they had a large, efficient army and capable generals. They utilised the newest developments in weaponry and transportation as well, which many of their enemies lacked. These latter developments allowed greater mobility over several different terrain types which were most common in many regions of China. Thus, in both ideology and practice, the Qin were militarily superior.[NEWLINE][TAB]Finally, the Qin empire had a geographical advantage due to its fertility and strategic situation, protected by mountains that made the state a natural stronghold. Its expanded agricultural output helped sustain Qin's large army with food and natural resources; the Wei River canal built in 246 BC was particularly significant in this respect.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the Warring States Period preceding the Qin Dynasty, the major states vying for dominance were Yan, Zhao, Qi, Chu, Han, Wei and Qin. The rulers of these states styled themselves as kings, rather than using the titles of lower nobility they had previously held. However, none elevated himself to believe that he had the "Mandate of Heaven," as the Zhou emperors had claimed, nor that he had the right to offer sacrificesâthey left this to the Zhou rulers.[PARAGRAPH:2]Before their conquest in the fourth and third centuries BC, the Qin suffered several setbacks. Shang Yang was executed in 338 BC due to a grudge by the leader King Wu over a student who had been executed because of Shang Yang's insistence that law applied even to nobility. There was also internal strife over the Qin succession in 307 BC, which decentralised Qin authority somewhat. Qin was defeated by an alliance of the other states in 295 BC, and shortly after suffered another defeat by the state of Zhao, because the majority of their army was then defending against the Qi. The aggressive statesman Fan Sui, however, soon came to power as prime minister even as the problem of the succession was resolved, and he began an expansionist policy that had originated in Jin and Qi, which prompted the Qin to attempt to conquer the other states.[NEWLINE][TAB]The Qin were swift in their assault on the other states. They first attacked the Han, directly east, and took the city of Yangdi in 230 BC. They then struck northward; the state of Zhao surrendered in 228 BC, and the northernmost state of Yan followed, falling in 226 BC. Next, Qin armies launched assaults to the east, and later the south as well; they took the Wei city of Daliang (now called Kaifeng) in 225 BC and forced the Chu to surrender by 223 BC. Lastly, they deposed the Zhou Dynasty's remnants in Luoyang and conquered the Qi, taking the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]When the conquests were complete in 221 BC, the leader of the Qin, King Zheng, who had first assumed the throne of the Qin state at age 13, became the effective ruler of China. He assumed his position as king with the abdication of his prime minister, Lu Buwei. He took on the name Qin Shihuang Di (meaning "First Emperor of the Qin"). The newly declared emperor ordered all weapons not in the possession of the Qin to be confiscated and melted down. The resulting metal was sufficient to build twelve large ornamental statues at the Qin's newly declared capital, Xianyang.[NEWLINE][TAB]In 214 BC Qin Shihuang secured his boundaries to the north with a fraction (100,000 men) of his large army, and sent the majority (500,000 men) south to seize still more land. Prior to the events leading to Qin dominance over China, they had gained possession of much of Sichuan to the southwest. The Qin army was unfamiliar with the jungle terrain, and it was defeated by the southern tribes' guerrilla warfare tactics with over 100,000 men lost. However, in the defeat Qin was successful in building a canal to the south, which they used heavily for supplying and reinforcing their troops during their second attack to the south. Building on these gains, the Qin armies conquered the coastal lands surrounding Guangzhou, and took the provinces of Fuzhou and Guilin. They struck as far south as Hanoi. After these victories in the south, Qin Shihuang moved over 100,000 prisoners and exiles to colonize the newly conquered area. In terms of extending the boundaries of his empire, the First Emperor was extremely successful in the south.[NEWLINE][TAB]However, while the empire at times was extended to the north, the Qin could rarely hold on to the land for long. The tribes of these locations, collectively called the Hu by the Qin, were free from Chinese rule during the majority of the Dynasty. Prohibited from trading with Qin Dynasty peasants, the Xiongnu tribe living in the Ordos region in northwest China often raided them instead, prompting the Qin to retaliate. After several campaigns and much effort, the region was conquered and agriculture was established; the peasants, however, were discontented and later revolted. The succeeding Han Dynasty also expanded into the Ordos due to overpopulation, but depleted their resources in the process. Owen Lattimore said of both Dynasties' attempts to conquer the Ordos, "conquest and expansion were illusory. There was no kind of success that did not create its own reaction." Indeed, this was true of the dynasty's borders in multiple directions; modern Xinjiang, Tibet, Manchuria, Inner Mongolia, and regions to the southeast were foreign to the Qin, and even areas over which they had military control were culturally distinct.[PARAGRAPH:2]Three assassination attempts were made on Qin Shihuang's life, leading him to become paranoid and obsessed with immortality. He died in 210 BC, while on a trip to the far eastern reaches of his empire in an attempt to procure an elixir of immortality from Taoist magicians, who claimed the elixir was stuck on an island guarded by a sea monster. The chief eunuch, Zhao Gao, and the prime minister, Li Si, hid the news of his death upon their return until they were able to alter his will to place on the throne the dead emperor's most pliable son, Huhai, who took the name of Qin Er Shi. They believed that they would be able to manipulate him to their own ends, and thus effectively control the empire. Qin Er Shi was, indeed, inept and pliable. He executed many ministers and imperial princes, continued massive building projects (one of his most extravagant projects was lacquering the city walls), enlarged the army, increased taxes, and arrested messengers who brought him bad news. As a result, men from all over China revolted, attacking officials, raising armies, and declaring themselves kings of seized territories.[NEWLINE][TAB]During this time, Li Si and Zhao Gao fell out among themselves, and Li Si was executed. Zhao Gao decided to force Qin Er Shi to commit suicide due to Qin Er Shi's incompetence. Upon this, Ziying, a nephew of Qin Er Shi, ascended the throne, and immediately executed Zhao Gao. Ziying, seeing that increasing unrest was growing among the people and that many local officials had declared themselves kings, attempted to cling to his throne by declaring himself one king among all the others. He was undermined by his ineptitude, however, and popular revolt broke out in 209 BC. When Chu rebels under the lieutenant Liu Bang attacked, a state in such turmoil could not hold for long. Ziying was defeated near the Wei River in 207 BC and surrendered shortly after; he was executed by the Chu leader Xiang Yu. The Qin capital was destroyed the next year, and this is considered by Derk Bodde, as well as other historians, to be the end of the Qin empire. Liu Bang then betrayed and defeated Xiang Yu, declaring himself Emperor Gaozu of the new Han Dynasty. Despite the short duration of the Qin Dynasty, it was very influential on the structure of future dynasties.

[TAB]Over the centuries the Yarlung Zangbo valley was the focus of ancient trade routes from India, China, and central Asia. Tibet emerged from an obscure history to flourish in the 7th cent. AD as an independent kingdom with its capital at Lhasa. Toward the end of the 12th century many Indian Buddhists, fleeing before the Muslim invasion, went to Tibet. In the 13th century Tibet fell under Mongol influence, which was to last until the 18th century. In 1270, Kublai Khan, emperor of China, was converted to Buddhism by the abbot of the Sakya lamasery. The abbot returned to Tibet to found the Sakya dynasty (1270-1340) and to become the first priest-king of Tibet. In 1720, the Ch'ing dynasty replaced Mongol rule in Tibet. China thereafter claimed suzerainty, often merely nominal.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the 18th century, British authorities in India attempted to establish relations with Lhasa, but Tibet maintained its traditional seclusion. Meanwhile, Ladakh, long part of Tibet, was lost to the rulers of Kashmir, and Sikkim was seized by Britain. In 1906, Britain recognized China's suzerainty over Tibet. However, the Tibetans were able to expel the Chinese from Tibet and reassert their independence (1912). After the death (1933) of the 13th Dalai Lama, Tibet gradually drifted back into the Chinese orbit. By a Tibetan-Chinese agreement (May, 1951), Tibet became a national autonomous region of China under the traditional rule of the Dalai Lama, but under the actual control of a Chinese Communist Commission.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Communist government introduced far-reaching land reforms and sharply curtailed the power of the monastic orders. Full-scale revolt broke out in March, 1959. The Chinese suppressed the rebellion, but the Dalai Lama managed to escape to India.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Chinese adopted brutal repressive measures, provoking charges from the Dalai Lama of genocide. Landholdings were seized, the lamaseries were virtually emptied, and thousands of monks were forced to find other work. In 1965 the Tibetan Autonomous Region was formally established. The Cultural Revolution, with its antireligious orientation, was disastrous for highly religious Tibet. Religious practices were banned and over 4,000 monasteries were destroyed. Though the ban was lifted in 1976 and some Buddhist temples have again been in operation since the early 1980s, Tibetans continue to complain of widespread discrimination by the Chinese. Several protests in Tibet in the late 1980s and early 1990s were violently suppressed by the Communist government and martial law was imposed in 1989. Demonstrations against Chinese rule have nevertheless continued. Moreover, in recent years other countries have increasingly raised the issue of human-rights violations in Tibet, and have pressured the Chinese government to moderate their stance in that region.

The Maccabees also spelled Machabees were a Jewish rebel army that took control of Judea, which had been a client state of the Seleucid Empire. They founded the Hasmonean dynasty, which ruled from 164 BCE to 63 BCE, reasserting the Jewish religion, expanding the boundaries of the Land of Israel and reducing the influence of Hellenism and Hellenistic Judaism.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the 2nd century BCE, Judea lay between the Ptolemaic Kingdom based in Egypt and the Seleucid empire based in Syria, kingdoms formed after the death of Alexander the Great (336-323 BCE). Judea had been under Ptolemaic rule, but fell to the Seleucids around 200 BCE. Judea at that time had been affected by the Hellenization begun by Alexander. Some Jews, mainly those of the urban upper class, notably the Tobiad family, wished to dispense with Jewish law and to adopt a Greek lifestyle. According to the historian Victor Tcherikover, the main motive for the Tobiads' Hellenism was economic and political. The Hellenizing Jews built a gymnasium in Jerusalem, competed in international Greek games, "removed their marks of circumcision and repudiated the holy covenant".[PARAGRAPH:1]When Antiochus IV Epiphanes (ca. 215164 BCE), became ruler of the Seleucid Empire in 175 BCE, the High Priest in Jerusalem was Onias III. To Antiochus, the High Priest was merely a local governor within his realm, who could be appointed or dismissed at will, while to orthodox Jews he was divinely appointed. Jason, the brother of Onias, bribed Antiochus to make him High Priest instead. Jason abolished the traditional theocracy and constituted Jerusalem as a Greek polis. Menelaus then bribed Antiochus and was appointed High Priest in place of Jason. Menelaus had Onias assassinated. Menelaus' brother Lysimachus stole holy vessels from the Temple, causing riots that led to his death. Menelaus was arrested for Onias' murder, and was arraigned before Antiochus, but he bribed his way out of trouble. Jason subsequently drove out Menelaus and became High Priest again. Antiochus pillaged the Temple, attacked Jerusalem and "led captive the women and children". From this point onwards, Antiochus pursued a zealous Hellenizing policy. He made possession of the Torah a capital offense and burned the copies he could find. He banned many traditional Jewish religious practices: Jewish sacrifice was forbidden, sabbaths and feasts were banned. Circumcision was outlawed, and mothers who circumcised their babies were killed along with their families. Altars to Greek gods were set up and animals prohibited to Jews were sacrificed on them. The idol of Olympian Zeus was placed on the altar of the Temple. The motives of Antiochus are unclear. He may have been incensed at the overthrow of his appointee, Menelaus, or he may have been responding to an orthodox Jewish revolt that drew on the Temple and the Torah for its strength and encouraged by a group of radical Hellenizers among the Jews.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the narrative of I Maccabees, after Antiochus issued his decrees forbidding Jewish religious practice, a rural Jewish priest from Modiin, Mattathias the Hasmonean, sparked the revolt against the Seleucid Empire by refusing to worship the Greek gods. Mattathias killed a Hellenistic Jew who stepped forward to offer a sacrifice to an idol in Mattathias' place. He and his five sons fled to the wilderness of Judah. After Mattathias' death about one year later in 166 BCE, his son Judas Maccabee led an army of Jewish dissidents to victory over the Seleucid dynasty in guerrilla warfare, which at first was directed against Hellenizing Jews, of whom there were many. The Maccabees destroyed pagan altars in the villages, circumcised boys and forced Jews into outlawry. The term Maccabees as used to describe the Jewish army is taken from the Hebrew word for "hammer".[PARAGRAPH:1]The revolt itself involved many battles, in which the Maccabean forces gained notoriety among the Syrian army for their use of guerrilla tactics. After the victory, the Maccabees entered Jerusalem in triumph and ritually cleansed the Temple, reestablishing traditional Jewish worship there and installing Jonathan Maccabee as high priest. A large Syrian army was sent to quash the revolt, but returned to Syria on the death of Antiochus IV. Its commander Lysias, preoccupied with internal Syrian affairs, agreed to a political compromise that restored religious freedom.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Jewish festival of Hanukkah celebrates the re-dedication of the Temple following Judah Maccabee's victory over the Seleucids. According to Rabbinic tradition, the victorious Maccabees could only find a small jug of oil that had remained uncontaminated by virtue of a seal, and although it only contained enough oil to sustain the Menorah for one day, it miraculously lasted for eight days, by which time further oil could be procured.[PARAGRAPH:2]Following the re-dedication of the temple, the supporters of the Maccabees were divided over the question of whether to continue fighting or not. When the revolt began under the leadership of Mattathias, it was seen as a war for religious freedom to end the oppression of the Seleucids. However, as the Maccabees realized how successful they had been, many wanted to continue the revolt and conquer other lands with Jewish populations or to convert their peoples. This policy exacerbated the divide between the Pharisees and Sadducees under later Hasmonean monarchs such as Alexander Jannaeus. Those who sought the continuation of the war were led by Judah Maccabee.[PARAGRAPH:1]On his death in battle in 160 BCE, Judah was succeeded as army commander by his younger brother, Jonathan, who was already High Priest. Jonathan made treaties with various foreign states, causing further dissent between those who merely desired religious freedom and those who sought greater power.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 142 BCE Jonathan was assassinated by Diodotus Tryphon, a pretender to the Seleucid throne, and was succeeded by Simon Maccabee, the last remaining son of Mattathias. Simon gave support to Demetrius II Nicator, the Seleucid king, and in return Demetrius exempted the Maccabees from tribute. Simon conquered the port of Joppa where the Gentile population were 'forcibly removed', the fortress of Gezer and expelled the garrison from the Acra in Jerusalem. In 140 BCE, he was recognised by an assembly of the priests, leaders and elders as high priest, military commander and ruler of Israel. Their decree became the basis of the Hasmonean kingdom. Shortly after, the Roman senate renewed its alliance with the Hasmonean kingdom and commanded its allies in the eastern Mediterranean to do so also. Although the Maccabees won autonomy, the region remained a province of the Seleucid Empire and Simon was required to provide troops to Antiochus VII Sidetes, the brother of Demetrius II. When Simon refused to give up the territory he had conquered, Antiochus took them by force.[PARAGRAPH:1]Simon was murdered in 134 BCE by his son-in-law Ptolemy, and was succeeded as high priest and king by his son John Hyrcanus I. Antiochus conquered the entire district of Judea, but refrained from attacking the Temple or interfering with Jewish observances. Judea was freed from Seleucid rule on the death of Antiochus in 129 BCE.[PARAGRAPH:1]Hasmonean rule lasted until 63 BCE, when the Roman general Pompey captured Jerusalem and subjected Israel to Roman rule, while the Hasmonean dynasty itself ended in 37 BCE when the Idumean Herod the Great became king of Israel and king of the Jews.

au Lac was the name of the Vietnamese state from 257 BC to 207 BC, succeeding Van Lang and preceding Nam Viet. The capital was Co Loa Citadel, located 35 km north of modern Hanoi.[PARAGRAPH:2]The country was created by Thuc Phan, who served as its only monarch, ruling under the royal title of An Duong Vuong and creating the Thuc Dynasty by uniting the mountainous Au Viet region (comprising what is today northernmost Vietnam and parts of southern China) with the more southerly Lac Viet (located in the Red River Delta of what is today northern Vietnam). Around 180 to 179 BC, Au Lac was conquered by Nam Viet, a kingdom that had its capital city, Panyu, around modern Guangzhou. Nam Viet rule lasted until 111 BC. In Vietnamese history, the rule of the Nam Viet kings is referred to as the Trieu Dynasty.

[TAB]The Hephthalites, also known as the 'White Huns', were people of obscure origins, possibly of Tibetan or Turkish stock. They were called Ephthalites by the Greeks, and Hunas by the Indians. There is no definite evidence that they are related to the Huns. The White Huns were an agricultural people with a developed set of laws. They were first mentioned by the Chinese, who described them (A.D. 125) as living in Dzungaria. They displaced the Scythians and conquered Sogdiana and Khorasan before 425. They crossed (425) the Syr Darya (Jaxartes) River and invaded Persia. Held off at first by Bahram Gur, they later (483-85) succeeded in making Persia tributary. After a series of wars (503-13) they were driven out of Persia, permanently lost the offensive, and were finally (557) defeated by Khosru I. The White Huns also invaded India and succeeded in extending their domain to include the Ganges valley. They temporarily overthrew the Gupta empire but were eventually driven out of India in 528 by a Hindu coalition. Although in Persia they had little effect, in India the White Huns influenced society by altering the caste system and disrupting the hierarchy of the ruling families. Some of the White Huns remained in India as a distinct group.

[TAB]The Huns were a group of nomadic people who, appearing from east of the Volga River, migrated into Europe c. AD 370 and established the vast Hunnic Empire there. Since de Guignes linked them with the Xiongnu, who had been northern neighbours of China 300 years prior to the emergence of the Huns, considerable scholarly effort has been devoted to investigating such a connection. However, there is no scholarly consensus on a direct connection between the dominant element of the Xiongnu and that of the Huns. Priscus mentions that the Huns had a language of their own; little of it has survived and its relationships have been the subject of debate for centuries. According to predominant theories, theirs was a Turkic language. Numerous other languages were spoken within the Hun pax including East Germanic, which was widely used as a lingua franca in the Hunnic territories.:202 Their main military technique was mounted archery.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Huns may have stimulated the Great Migration, a contributing factor in the collapse of the western Roman Empire. They formed a unified empire under Attila the Hun, who died in 453; their empire broke up the next year. Their descendants, or successors with similar names, are recorded by neighbouring populations to the south, east, and west as having occupied parts of Eastern Europe and Central Asia approximately from the 4th century to the 6th century. Variants of the Hun name are recorded in the Caucasus until the early 8th century.

Rouran, Juan-Juan or Zhu-Zhu was the name of a confederation of nomadic tribes on the northern borders of Inner China from the late 4th century until the middle 6th century. It has sometimes been hypothesized that the Rouran are identical to the Eurasian Avars who later appeared in Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]The term Rouran is a Mandarin Chinese transcription of the pronunciation of the name the confederacy used to refer to itself. Ruanruan and Ruru remained in modern usage despite once being derogatory. They derived from orders given by the Emperor Taiwu of Northern Wei, who waged war against the Rouran and intended to intimidate the confederacy.[PARAGRAPH:2]The power of the Rouran was broken by an alliance of Göktürks, the Chinese Northern Qi and Northern Zhou dynasties and tribes in Central Asia in 552.

[TAB]Kalinka was an early republic in central-eastern India, which comprised most of the modern state of Orissa/Utkal (pronounced as Orissa), as well as the Andhra region of the bordering state of Andhra Pradesh. It was a rich and fertile land that extended from the river Damodar/Ganges to Godavari and from Bay of Bengal to Amarkantak range in the West.
